awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II:  Collaborative Research: Ceramic, Composite and Optical Materials Center
awd_abstract_narration:
The Ceramic, Composite and Optical Materials Center (CCOMC) is an NSF Phase II, I/UCRC which is managed by Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey (Rutgers) and Clemson University (Clemson). The Center is integrated between the two university partners and is directed by an Industrial Advisory Board (IAB) comprised of 21 multinational member companies and national laboratories. The mission of the CCOMC is to develop new, interdisciplinary technologies to increase the level of ceramic, polymer and optical material science, technology and engineering and to transfer these technologies to its industrial members to foster the development of competitive, reproducible ceramic, polymer fiber and composites made of them for advanced, high performance systems. The continuation proposal aims to broaden the scope of the Center to new areas that are technologically complementary and will lead towards the Center?s long terms self-sufficiency. 
The programs within the Center focus on the creation of new materials, new synthesis and processing methods, process based models, measurements and characterization methods for complex, integrated systems and devices. CCOMC began with program thrusts in ceramic and polymeric materials and processing, nanoparticulates and processes, opaque armor ceramics, optical material synthesis and processing and materials for energy conversion. As we move forward into the next five years, we will expand the scope of our research to include new research thrust areas in ceramic matrix composites and superhard, high temperature material. In addition we will explore green/ecofriendly processing as potential thrusts. It is critical to long-term self-sufficiency that we not only attract a broader base of members, but  also be successful in securing Federal funding to strengthens new and existing thrusts to improve the visibility of the Center within both universities and abroad.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The outcome of the Center has been to create a strong working relationship between the two partner universities, Rutgers and Clemson. This led to many research programs exploring relevant fundamental science in the synthesis, processing, characterization and property evaluation for a broad scope of ceramics, optical materials and polymeric materials. This led to the Center being a place where over 35 members over the life of the CCOMC benefited from the research, facilities and access to a diverse faculty in materials science and engineering. Over the life of the CCOMC more than 19 graduate students received PhD's and 1/3 of these joined center members upon graduating. Faculty published 169 peer reviewed papers. In addition, many faculty began and remain as consultants for our members.

Many topics were explored in the center ranging from unique powder synthesis, new fiber processing methods and new material developed. One example is Prof. Riman's work in hydrothermal processing which led to the spin off company Solidia. This company is based upon green processing and carbon sequestration in creating a new type of cement. Another is work that Prof. Haber on armor materials. The material he developed is 23% lighter and 67% more ballistic resistant for the Army. US center members are now developing these materials for the Army.

The center had changed during COVID when many members had to leave the center.  During this time, the partner university, Clemson, had to withdraw from the center due to its inability to meet the minimum requirements for corporate membership. Rutgers continued through the end of the Phase II. Rutgers, one of the original IUCRC schools, will maintain a cooperative program now that the NSF funding ended. The strong response from its member is a testament to the benefit that the partnership with NSF has provided.

The benefit of the NSF IUCRC has been significant to both universities. The ability to collaborate closely between the two schools, but also with industry and government laboratories was the framework that Rutgers, along with Johns Hopkins, Cal Tech and the University of Delaware won the $90M Army Research Laboratory Materials for Extreme Dynamic Environments 10 year program. The IUCRC model showed how multiuniversity programs can closely work with industry and government. The framework for the memoranda of understanding, patent handling management structure is the basis by which this and a number of NATO, DARPA and ARL programs were competed and won. The IUCRC program is the unique model than is the basis for programs to grow.


Last Modified: 03/21/2023
Modified by: Richard A Haber
